node.title: ‘A Lot of Uncertainty’: Covid Surge Puts Many Americans on Edge About Traveling
node.alt: Airline travel during the holiday season was expected to increase 184 percent from last year, according to AAA.
node.description: Fear of the virus is causing some to rethink their holiday plans, while others say they will proceed, perhaps with more caution.
node.content: ["Across the nation, Covid-19 cases are surging and the Omicron variant is spreading, throwing the scheduling of schools, concerts and sports leagues into question. Just days away from a holiday weekend, Americans are also grappling with whether to change their traveling or gathering plans.", "Millions are forging ahead, but, for many, a sense of unease has crept in.", "\u201cMy entire family is pretty uncertain about what to do there, what the rules should be,\u201d Max Farmer, 24, who lives in San Francisco, said. \u201cWith Omicron, there\u2019s just a lot of uncertainty.\u201d", "Mr. Farmer has plans to go to Minnesota this month and see his family for the first time in three years. But he said he was worried about the possibility of getting them sick, particularly a sister who was pregnant.", "\u201cIt\u2019s definitely something that goes through your head while you\u2019re traveling,\u201d he said.", "More than 109 million Americans are expected to travel between Dec. 23 and Jan. 2, a 34 percent increase from last year, according to AAA. The number of airline passengers alone is projected to rise 184 percent from last year.", "On Sunday, Dr. Anthony Fauci, the nation\u2019s top infectious disease expert, said that it was OK for Americans to travel and gather, but he strongly emphasized that people take precautions.", "\u201cIf you\u2019re vaccinated and you\u2019re boosted, and you take care when you go into congregate settings like airports to make sure you continually wear your mask, you should be OK,\u201d Dr. Fauci said on \u201cMeet the Press\u201d on NBC. He urged air travelers to remain masked during flights.", "Caiden Nason, a political campaigner in San Francisco, said he would be flying to see family in rural Southern California. \u201cI\u2019m a little nervous,\u201d he said. But he added: \u201cI just got tested today. My parents will all get tested, too. I will double mask on the airplane.\u201d", "Sally Avery, a native of Columbus, Ohio, who now lives in France, was in Cleveland to visit her daughter. She said the uncertainty over the Covid surge caused her to leave early and miss the holidays with her daughter. If France went into lockdown, she said at Hopkins International Airport in Cleveland, \u201cI could be here for a long time, and I can\u2019t do that.\u201d", "Monica Neal of Smyrna, Ga., took a trip to South Africa on Thanksgiving, but she said she ended up getting stuck there for days because of the Omicron variant. She canceled a trip to Europe this month.", "\u201cI have traveled internationally twice this year, and I\u2019ve fortunately been very safe and very healthy,\u201d she said. \u201cI didn\u2019t want to push that luck.\u201d", "Many others said they had no plans to adjust. Blake Howe, a software engineer in Roswell, Ga., said he was going on a cruise in January for his 30th birthday. He planned the trip months ago and received his shots and the booster.", "Mr. Howe said he knew that cruise liners had been breeding grounds for Covid-19 in the past, but he\u2019s not concerned this time. \u201cThey\u2019re requiring full vaccination, as well as the booster,\u201d he said, adding that \u201cthey\u2019re at reduced capacity on the ship.\u201d", "Some who were interviewed weren\u2019t planning to travel anywhere \u2014 and were happy to stay put.", "\u201cI wouldn\u2019t want to go anywhere right now,\u201d said Monica Rokes, a 69-year-old retired bank teller in Camden, Maine, who was shopping in the town of Rockland. She said she had started taking more precautions in recent days \u2014 washing her hands more often, using hand sanitizer, avoiding large crowds and groups of people, and wearing her mask.", "\u201cIt\u2019s very frightening,\u201d she said of the recent surge. \u201cI\u2019m doing everything I can do to stay safe.\u201d", "For those planning to attend large gatherings, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is still recommending that everyone get vaccinated before getting together with multiple generations of the same family. For indoor gatherings, the C.D.C. is asking people to consider taking an at-home rapid test beforehand.", "Eugene DeMarco, 35, who has a bakery stand at the West Side Market in Cleveland, said that his family typically had a big holiday get-together and that this year would be no different.", "\u201cWe aren\u2019t concerned at all,\u201d said Mr. DeMarco, who is unvaccinated and was not wearing a mask. \u201cAbout 60 or so of our family will be getting together. The Covid-19 infections are the reality, and you have to get used to it. Can\u2019t be driven by fear.\u201d", "J\u2019Rycee Johnson, a 20-year-old in Baltimore who works for a T-shirt company, said that he didn\u2019t have extensive plans but that nothing was changing for him, either, adding that he was unconcerned by the virus.", "\u201cI don\u2019t take vaccines at all,\u201d he said, citing his spiritual belief that God heals. \u201cThat\u2019s basically what it comes down to for me.\u201d", "In Springfield, Mo., Mary Ann Johnson, 57, is looking forward to celebrating with her family on Christmas Eve, even though she\u2019s aware that the Omicron variant is spreading quickly.", "She worries about contracting the virus from the general public or from clients at her workplace; she works with individuals who have been arrested in connection with impaired driving. But she said she felt comfortable with just her family: \u201call three of my kids, all five of the grandsons and two foster grandsons.\u201d", "Still, Ms. Johnson is making one adjustment: No hugs or kisses, she said.", "\u201cMy daughter-in-law has lupus, so we are extremely cautious with her,\u201d Ms. Johnson said. She added: \u201cWe all know how we feel. With the virus, that\u2019s good enough.\u201d"]
